thread.title: Twice stricken by cancer, now a competitive powerlifter
thread.title_full: Twice stricken by cancer, now a competitive powerlifter

author: Amanda Saxton
title: Twice stricken by cancer, now a competitive powerlifter
text:
Twice stricken by cancer, now a competitive powerlifter AMANDA SAXTON Last updated 05:00, February 26 2017 LAWRENCE SMITH/Stuff.co.nz 
In 2013 Elouise Hemming was diagnosed with Lymphoma and told she had weeks to live. She was also a solo mother of one. The following four years were spent fighting the disease. She's now a personal trainer with a positive story to pass on to others. 
Four years ago Elouise Hemming was told to say goodbye to her baby daughter because she only had weeks to live. 
The Auckland woman's lymphoma had returned after a year in remission; "stage four cancer, again, and it was in my stomach, in my bladder, in my colon, in my rectum," she said. 
Now the 28-year-old is a competitive powerlifter and self-described life of the party. LAWRENCE SMITH 
Twenty-eight-year-old Hemming has two years left in remission before being declared cured of lymphoma. 
When her doctor told her death was nigh, Hemming replied "f... that!" 
READ MORE: 
"I said that because that's me, I fight, and that's what I did." LAWRENCE SMITH 
Mother-of-one Elouise Hemming beat cancer twice to became a powerlifting personal trainer. 
She battled her disease and the strain of motherhood within a disintegrating relationship. When the relationship and her chemotherapy ended together, Hemming turned to the gym for direction. 
She said cancer taught her to see exercise as a privilege. 
"Working out is uncomfortable, but that aspect gets you tougher mentally," she said. "It's helped me become a better mum and friend." LAWRENCE SMITH 
Mother-of-one Elouise Hemming beat cancer twice to became a powerlifting personal trainer. 
It also gave her a career - Hemming became a personal trainer one year after going into remission. Ad Feedback 
"I get a lot of joy from seeing people get stronger," she explained. 
"I'm not interested in the aesthetic side of things, I'm interested in making a long term improvement - helping someone avoid old age in a nursing home, for example." 
She is cautious about sharing her story with clients, wary some may perceive her as "guilt tripping". 
"I don't want to be like 'look at me, there are no excuses' ... It's about inserting my experience somehow when they're finding motivation hard," she said. 
The gym-junkie has also taken up powerlifting. 
Despite nausea, fluid retention, and heart problems that haunt her post-cancer body, Hemming can dead-lift 120kg. 
She competed for the first time two months ago and aims to enter the Auckland Powerlifting Championships next year. 
Along with her rallying health, her housing situation has improved since she was re-revaged by cancer. 
Hemming left a mouldy apartment for a "way better" flat shared with another single mum. 
"We take the 'it takes a village to raise a child' saying to heart," she said. 
Motherhood, powerlifting, work, and "partying enough to make up for all those sick years" keeps her occupied - but doctors' aren't out of Hemming's life yet. 
Every few weeks for the next two years she needs blood tests to check she's still in remission. 
Asked whether she feared a third bout of cancer, Hemming gave a firm "no". 
"I prefer to practice gratitude." - Sunday Star Times
